article.title: The specificity and robustness of long-distance connections in weighted, interareal connectomes

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following species is NOT represented in Figure 1?
choices: Mouse
Rat
Macaque
Drosophila

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the matrices in the top row of Figure 1 represent?
choices: Euclidean distance matrices
Connectomes
Functional connectivity matrices
Correlation matrices

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between edge weight and distance in interareal brain networks, as shown in Figure 2a?
choices: Positive correlation
No correlation
Negative correlation
Variable, depending on the species

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2c shows the frequency of edge weights. What is the general trend observed for the relationship between connection weight and the likelihood of being a long-distance connection?
choices: Weaker connections are more likely to be long-distance connections.
There is no relationship between connection weight and the likelihood of being a long-distance connection.
Stronger connections are more likely to be long-distance connections.
The relationship depends on the species.

multiple_choice_question.text: What metric is used in Figure 3c to quantify the diversity of connection lengths for each brain area?
choices: Standard deviation
Mean
Interquartile range
Variance

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3f shows the standardized overlap of clusters with functional systems. What does a large orange circle indicate?
choices: Areas within those systems are less likely to be co-clustered.
Areas within those systems are equally likely to be co-clustered as expected by chance.
Areas within those systems are more likely to be co-clustered than expected by chance.
There is no relationship between cluster overlap and functional systems.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of Figure 4, what does the parameter "a" represent?
choices: The edge strength-to-distance parameter
The number of shortest paths
The connection weight
The Euclidean distance between brain areas

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding from Figure 4, regarding the role of long-distance connections in shortest paths?
choices: Long-distance connections are the dominant contributors to shortest paths.
Long-distance connections play an increasingly important role as "a" increases.
Long-distance connections play a minor role in shortest paths, especially as "a" increases.
Removing long-distance connections has a greater impact than removing short connections on shortest paths.

multiple_choice_question.text: What measure is used in Figure 5 to quantify the similarity between connectivity profiles of nearby and distant inputs to a brain area?
choices: Euclidean distance
Pearson correlation
Cosine similarity
Jaccard index

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the consistently negative distribution of standardized similarity scores in Figure 5b indicate?
choices: Long-distance and short-range connections have similar connectivity profiles.
Long-distance and short-range connections have dissimilar connectivity profiles.
There is no relationship between the similarity of connectivity profiles and connection distance.
The relationship between connectivity profile similarity and connection distance varies depending on the species.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the randomized networks shown in Figure 6?
choices: To show that long-range connectivity is random.
To control for the degree sequence, edge-length distribution, and edge-weight distribution.
To highlight the differences in connectivity profiles between empirical and random networks.
To demonstrate the importance of using a specific definition of "long-range."

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the consistently higher mean cosine similarity of long-range connectivity profiles in the empirical networks compared to the randomized networks (Figure 6b) suggest?
choices: Long-range connectivity is random and unstructured.
Long-range connectivity exhibits non-random correlations, suggesting redundancy.
Long-range connections primarily serve to reduce topological distance.
There are no significant differences between empirical and randomized long-range connectivity profiles.

multiple_choice_question.text: What dynamical model is used in Figure 7 to simulate brain activity?
choices: Ising model
Linearized Wilson-Cowan model
Hopfield network
Kuramoto model

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding of Figure 7c, regarding the effect of removing long-distance connections on functional diversity?
choices: Removing long-distance connections increases functional diversity.
Removing long-distance connections has no consistent effect on functional diversity.
Removing long-distance connections decreases functional diversity.
The effect of removing long-distance connections depends on the species.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of analysis is depicted in Figure 8?
choices: Seed-based correlation analysis
Independent component analysis
Multi-layer modularity maximization
Graph theoretical analysis

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of using a multi-layer approach in Figure 8, as opposed to analyzing low- and high-resolution data separately?
choices: To identify modules that are consistent across different spatial scales.
To reduce the computational complexity of the analysis.
To account for differences in data quality between the two datasets.
To visualize the hierarchical organization of brain networks.
